I regard the central issue of abortion to be whether or not it is permissable to sepperate consensual sex as an act from it's reproductive function. 
 
 Humans, like it or not, are socially sexual animals; to copulate for reasons other than procreation is a natural behavior in us. Recently in our history, it has become possible for us to chemically or mechanically interfere with various processes of conception in order to permit "social sex" to be practiced without even the low rates of fertillity-per-copulation which are typical of unaltered humans.
 
 It has been practical throughout the period of settled human history for societies to produce stabillity by rationing of sexual liscence amongst individuals. This practice insured that most males were granted sexual rights to at least one woman, thus counteracting the state where women would gravitate to a few males as their procreative partners and men would be in constant competition for this honor. This also created stable and predictable systems of family structure and inheritance. The fear of societies scorn and financial ruin in the event of an extramarital pregnancy was used to enforce compliance to this regime, and to liscence in a sense the creation of new citizens. (Humans tend towards monogamy in their uncivillised state anyway, but without coercion these lifetime pair-bonds tend to be flexible and permit limited phillandering, especially during periods of lessened fertillity on the part of the woman.)
 
 The recent advent of reliable methods of birth control has been interpreted in two very distinct ways by individuals:
 
 A ) The anti-abortion crowd takes it's cues from a traditional concept of sex as procreation. They are, in fact opposed emotionally to most forms of birthcontrol, since their answer for every condition is "Don'y have sex if you aren't willing to make a baby." They are additionally incensed by abortion, because their belief in the inevitabillity of childbirth given sex makes them see even the earliest phases of conception as a child fait'accompli. It is true that in the case of late term abortions they have a fair case presenting the aborted pheatus as "more child than tumor". However, they vastly overestimate the regard which pregnancies and even young children were held in earlier societies, a product of wistful yearning for the past misinformed by modernities low miscarriage and infant mortality rates. The arguments used by this camp focus on the conflation of the abortive act with the destruction of something human-like; this is fairly honest when applied to late-term pheatuses, but quite a stretch when applied to a few undifferentiated cells, which they also like to call "babies".
 
 B ) The pro-abortion crowd is a product of a belief in the rational construction of ethics, and these people have been quick to reconsider sexual morality in the light of practical birth-control and safer surgical abortions. The existance of birth-control technologies has instilled in this portion of the population an expectation of sepperabillity between sex and chilbirth. Having seized back from traditional society the right of social sex, they are inscensed at the idea that fetillisation ought to condemn a woman to bearing a child. These people are fairly realistic about the viabillity and humanity of early term pregnancies while the dogmas of their' movement cause them to take some outlandish stands with regard to late-term pheatuses. The most notable flaw in this camps thinking is the failure to recognise the inherent negativity of the thing they are defending; there are no happy abortion stories to be told, as abortion is always a human tragedy even when it leads to the best outcome. The Pro-abortion camps arguments usually rely on a "slippery slope" rationale, as they are more likely to recognise that birth controll and sexual morality are the underlying issues than are their counterparts. While I would not say that this argument is "better" or "truer" than those of the anti-abortion lobby, they do address the underlying contention more directly, which I believe frames a more productive debate. In short, the "slippery slope" argument shows cognizance that the pressure to restrict all forms of family planning will not go away with the elimination of abortion, and tries to establih the sepperabillity of sex and childbirth as a basic right of modern persons.
